page.title: 07TRANSPORT - BURGHFIELD
page.content: THE Kennet & Avon Canal is the sole surviving waterway across southern England. Completed 1810 linking Reading/Bristol (87\ miles). It's initial success promoting trade for agricultural products, coal, timber, etc. was shortlived because of Great Western Railway and subsequently growth of road traffic following 1st World War. Despite disuse and decay Canal survived until 1950 when stoppage was declared between Newbury and Reading because condition was considered dangerous. Further restrictions followed and Canal has not been completely re-opened since. 1963 British Waterways Board formed and its duties re: Canal included use for commercial transportation and as an amenity. Restoration is underway with aim of Canal being fully navigable.
